results.title: About nothing = O nicem
results.creator_credit: William Bukovy, Pavel Hobl, Jan Brychta, Vlastimil Brodsky, Kratky Film and Vstredni Pujcouna Film
results.brief_description: An unusual animated story about a character called “Nothing”, that teases the mind in a delightful and challenging way. “Nothing” gets into the most difficult situations but - after finding a job in a circus he discovers he can successfully help the sad clown and others become happy and able to make fun again. Note: Czechoslovakian language - no subtitles.

results.title: About flowers
results.creator_credit: Rene Jodoin, Frank Spiller and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A nature lesson taught in a field of flowers. Two children playing in a meadow learn from an elderly neighbour about the recurring growth cycle of the flowering plant. They see how and why flowers attract bees, how fertilisation occurs, how seeds form and new plants come to life in spring. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: About face
results.creator_credit: Chris James and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: This film gallops through over 60 facial transformations, including animated caricatures of Mick Jagger, Oscar Wilde, The Queen, The Duke of Edinburgh, Prince Charles, Pablo Picasso, Idi Amin, Salvador Dali, Adolf Hitler, The Marx Brothers, and David Bowie. Music by Claude Jouvin.

results.title: About conception and contraception
results.creator_credit: Dorothy Courtois and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Animated drawings illustrate how conception occurs and the way that various birth control devices, surgical methods and ‘the pill’ function in effecting contraception. Without spoken commentary this film is designed to be used by professional personnel.

results.title: About a dollar's worth
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Department of Defence, Defence Public Relations
results.brief_description: Employs constructive montage and synthetic music to illustrate the benefits of the Royal Australian Air Force to Australians. Looks at training of personnel, rescue work, training of overseas personnel, and social activities.

results.title: Abortion: stories from the north and south
results.brief_description: A documentary that looks at abortion and how it has affected many women from all cultures and social classes throughout the history of human beings. Women from all over the world are interviewed and they discuss the way in which their societies deal with abortion.

results.title: Abortion: a tale of two cities
results.brief_description: Uses two dramatised case studies to highlight some of the problems faced by different sections of the community, in the provision of abortion. Intended for women’s groups and for people concerned with health education. Cast includes: Judy Snape, Marlene Sidaway, Max Smith, Derry Jordan, Fred Grant. Narrated by Peter Ellis.

results.title: Aborigines of the Northern Territory: scouting outpost
results.creator_credit: Cinesound Movietone, Bob Kingsbury, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Scouting has become an important activity among young Aboriginal children of Maningrida on the Arafura Sea in Northern Australia. In 1964 a school teacher introduced scouting, and its popularity led to the growth of the movement to include Cubs, Rovers and Guides. Young people from eleven tribes in the area are involved.

results.title: Aboriginal Rules (2006)
results.brief_description: Independently funded 55 minute documentary produced in 2006 by Warlpiri Media Association. Directed by Liam Campbell and co-directed by Francis Jupurrurla Kelly and Neil Jupurrurla White, Aboriginal Rules follows the Yuendumu Magpies AFL team for a year. Over that time we see the highs and lows of their aspiration to win the Central Australia Football League Grand Final. We also get an insight into the challenges of young Aboriginal men growing up on settlements.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

results.title: Aboriginal legends. No. 3
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal legends gathered from tribal elders by student teachers from Kormilda College, Darwin are retold with accompanying illustrations by the students. The titles include: “Why the Emu cannot fly” - storyteller and artist, Nugget Jabangadi James; “Inganarr, the giant Serpent” - story by Bunug, artist Nathanael Maralngura; “The Bat and the Rainbow” - story by Anastasia Kelantumana, artist Suzanne Chalmers. These stories and pictures can be found in the book entitled “Djugurba”. Narrated by Juliana Allan, Wynne Nelson and Peter Gwynne.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
